messageBody:
Oh man, even after a good lunch, I'm not sure that I'm up to explaining classloader conflicts, but I'll grab a fresh cup of coffee and try. :-)

The issue all boils down to who knows what and when. I suspect that the reason that you have not had this problem on Windows is that you have most likely set the CLASSPATH environment variable ahead of time and it is in the environment when you start Ant. Ant uses the existing CLASSPATH value and adds the JAR files from it's lib directory to that list. It then performs all of the rest of it's work with that combined personal classpath. This would explain why it can find JUnit and why JUnit can find everything that it needs.

/------------------\
|System Classloader|
\------------------/
|
|
V
/------------------\
| Ant Classloader |
\------------------/
|
|
V
/------------------\
| JUnit Classloader|
\------------------/

Now, my personal recommendation is to run with an empty CLASSPATH in your environment. This helps prevent things working by accident. I either set the classpath within a script that calls my program or I build a classpath within Ant when compiling and building. The reason that just adding the JUnit JAR file to the classpath within Ant doesn't work (for example with the <PATH> declaration) is that you are trying to add JUnit to Ant after Ant has started and already built it's own classpath.

/------------------\
|System Classloader|
\------------------/
|
|
.-------------------------.
| |
/------------------\ /------------------\
| Ant Classloader | | JUnit Classloader|
\------------------/ \------------------/

This gives you parallel classloaders, with the danger that one classloader might have a different classpath than the other, as well as some of the other nefarious stuff that goes on in classloaders, including class-caching (always an opportunity for confusion).

So, the best comprimise between how you did things with Windows and moving to the Mac, is to dump classloader troublemakers like JUnit into your Ant lib directory.

All that being said, I strongly recommend the Mac for development work. I class myself as a switcher: I switched from Linux to OS X (and my wife switched from Windows to OS X). I love my Macs (a dual G4 desktop and an iBook for those get up and go moments).

I hope this helps. I know what I wanted to say, but it's a very complex subject and I've been interupted a millions times while typing this so far! ;-)

Simon
